clinical_study.brief_title: The Effects of the Hopeful Outdoor Parkinson Exercise (HOPE) Program on Improving Balance Performance and Reducing Fall Rate in Parkinsonian Non-fallers and Single Fallers
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of the Hopeful Outdoor Parkinson Exercise (HOPE) Program on Improving Balance Performance and Reducing Fall Rate in Parkinsonian Non-fallers and Single Fallers - a Randomized Controlled Trial

oversight_info.authority: Hong Kong:The Hong Kong Polytechnic University Human Subjects Ethics Sub-commitee

brief_summary.textblock: To determine whether the 8-week Hopeful Outdoor Parkinson's Exercise (HOPE) Program would be effective in reducing fall rate, improving balance performance, balance confidence, physical functions, gait parameters, disease-specific motor performance and health-related quality of life in Parkinson's disease (PD) non-fallers and single fallers.

detailed_description.textblock: Previous studies demonstrated that multi-modal balance training program was effective in improving balance performance in people with PD. However they did not include all the balance domains and outdoor fall-prone activities have been overlooked. And it is still inconclusive if these interventions could reduce fall rate and enhance balance confidence. We designed an exercise program based on the framework of the Balance Evaluation Systems Test (BESTest) to target six balance domains including biomechanical constraints, stability limits and verticality, anticipatory postural adjustments, reactive postural responses, sensori-motor integration and dynamic gait control.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline Balance Systems Evaluation Test at post 4-week training, post 8-week training, 2-month follow-up and 6-month follow-up

secondary_outcome.measure: changes from baseline Activities-specific Balance Confidence Scale at post 4-week training, post 8-week training, 2-month follow-up and 6-month follow-up

other_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline Movement Disorder Society - Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) III at post 4-week training, post 8-week training, 2-month follow-up and 6-month follow-up

arm_group.description: 4-week indoor balance training followed by 4-week outdoor balance training with fall-prone activities in malls and park

arm_group.description: upper limb and hand stretching, strengthening and agility exercises, knot-tying and Chinese calligraphy
